body: Hey @murgatroid99! I tried these changes and we continue to see the `updater_proc` object being replaced. Do you want to do a hangout and I can show you our setup?

FWIW, I suspect line 266 is the cause:

``` c
plugin.state = (void*)proc;
```
Are you using any credentials `compose` functions? I just realized that I didn't fix the garbage collection marking for those.

Yes, we are using `compose`. Here is our code to create the credentials. The `client` object is a Google::Auth/Signet object.

``` ruby
creds = GRPC::Core::ChannelCredentials.new.compose \
  GRPC::Core::CallCredentials.new client.updater_proc
```
OK, I think that last commit should fix it.

Unfortunately it does not fix it. With my change to `grpc_rb_call_credentials_callback_rescue` attempts to call the credentials print the following debug message:

```
E0314 14:16:29.451012000 123145303392256 credentials.c:1162] Getting metadata from plugin failed with error: undefined method `call' for #<Hash:0x007fce53d99990>
E0314 14:16:29.451023000 123145303392256 client_auth_filter.c:93] Client side authentication failure: Credentials failed to get metadata.
```
I think I see the problem now. The credentials objects are keeping the proc alive, but the call and channel aren't keeping the credentials objects alive.

You sure it isn't because the proc object is dereferenced and the pointer to the proc is passed in on the plugin? When ruby moves the location of the proc object that pointer won't be updated and will point to whatever ruby puts there. That's how it reads to me, but I admit I haven't been able to crack this problem yet. :)

If Ruby ever moved objects around in memory, then there would be no way to ever hold a reference to a Ruby object in C, and `rb_gc_mark` would be meaningless.

I think that what you're seeing is Ruby objects getting garbage collected, and the pointer pointing to new objects allocated in the same location (i.e. use after free).

Ruby definitely moves objects around in memory. That's the whole point of a generational GC. In my patch a struct is created to hold the reference to the VALUE, and the location of the struct isn't going to be touched by ruby's GC, so a pointer to it is safe to pass to GRPC.

Oh, my addition of `rb_funcall(exception_object, rb_intern("to_s"), 0));` isn't needed for my patch, that just helps me see what method is being called on what object. I do think something like that would be more useful for debug messages, but isn't needed for the patch to work.
@murgatroid99 I sent you a PR (murgatroid99/grpc#2) to add my changes to this PR. I'm running our acceptance tests over and over with it and haven't had a single failure yet.

I don't see how that could be the problem. A VALUE is just a number (a `uintptr_t` on most systems), and in some cases it is actually cast to a pointer. Casting it to a pointer and then back should not be able to cause the kind of failures we are seeing.

I've got multiple successful test runs that show that my patch this does address the problem. Also, if I don't include the call to `rb_gc_mark(proc_wrapper->proc);` in my patch then it doesn't work.

I'm looking for a URL that explains how the ruby GC works, but I'm not finding what I'm looking for. Short answer is I don't know what specific mechanism ruby uses to keep the VALUE pointing to the correct location in memory. But all evidence points to this being the cause of the errors and segfaults.

I'm pretty sure that the change that you just made only actually worked because you called `rb_gc_mark(proc_wrapper->proc)` in the initialization function, removing it from garbage collection forever. The `VALUE` to struct change was orthogonal to that, and probably didn't make a difference.

I think the change I just made should properly fill out the missing parts of the reference graph needed to keep the credentials references around long enough.

Gotcha. My change to mark the proc object makes sense if the problem is that that it was garbage collected. I've pulled your latest change and our tests are passing! So this does seem to solve our issue. I'll run more tests over night just to make sure.

Thanks!

![mlp-awesome](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/730/13763064/0cc04af4-ea09-11e5-8a43-a72f5b0ba203.jpg)
Great. I'm glad I could help.
This is fantastic! Thank you @murgatroid99 and @blowmage for working through this!!!
We've run several test runs using the code in this PR and had no problems at all. :+1: for days.
Ping
@nicolasnoble I would love to see this accepted and released soon.
@murgatroid99 and @nicolasnoble Please excuse me if this is published elsewhere, but is there a date for the next release that would contain this fix?
We expect the release to be early next week.
@murgatroid99 Fantastic!!! Thank you!
@jtattermusch C# code coverage failed ?
Otherwise, LGTM.
coverage failure is a known flake.

@jtattermusch Thank you! Can we still expect the release to be early this week?

/cc @jgeewax

@quartzmo  it is our plan to release soon (hopefully this week, early next week the latest).

@murgatroid99, can you please backport this change to 0.13 branch?
